content.text: Bacterial conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva caused by bacteria. It is a common cause of "pink eye," characterized by conjunctival injection and purulent or mucopurulent discharge. Common causative organisms include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. It is typically self-limiting but is often treated with topical antibiotics to speed recovery and reduce transmission.

pairs.value: Redness, grittiness, irritation, and eyelids stuck together upon waking.
Purulent or mucopurulent discharge, conjunctival injection (usually bilateral, but can start in one eye), and eyelid edema. Vision is typically normal.

content.text: Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on history and physical examination. Cultures are generally reserved for severe, recurrent, or refractory cases, or in newborns (ophthalmia neonatorum).
While often self-resolving within 1-2 weeks, topical antibiotic therapy is commonly prescribed to shorten the clinical course, reduce complications, and prevent spread.

appliesTo.description: Adults and children with non-severe bacterial conjunctivitis

components.drug: Fluoroquinolone drops (e.g., moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin, ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin)

regimenData.notes: Fluoroquinolones are often reserved for more severe cases or contact lens wearers due to concerns about resistance. Choice may depend on cost and availability.

Good hand hygiene to prevent transmission.
Avoiding touching or rubbing the eyes.

conditions.differentiatingFeatures: Typically has a watery (serous) discharge, often associated with a recent upper respiratory infection, and preauricular lymphadenopathy is more common.
Characterized by intense itching, bilateral involvement, watery or stringy discharge, and a history of allergies.
Involves the cornea and is associated with significant pain, photophobia, and potentially reduced visual acuity. Requires urgent ophthalmologic evaluation.
A medical emergency characterized by severe eye pain, headache, nausea, halos around lights, a fixed mid-dilated pupil, and elevated intraocular pressure.
